titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Snead Papers, 1966-1989 UA.90.F81
titlestmt.author: Cassidee Knott.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:13:13 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the gathered works of James A. Snead from 1966 to 1989. The collection includes his written works, both fiction and non-fiction; research; personal activities; corresepondence; and prior research done about Snead utilizing the materials in this collection. The Non-Fiction subseries encompasses his work on subjects such as Benito Cereno, James Joyce, Black Cinema, and Thomas Mann. Much of the research in the Research series pertains to these non-fiction works, but also include resources on Snead's other interests in German politics, book reviews, and general research on other writers. The Personal Acitivities series houses some of Snead's course work and lectures, as well as information from his time at Yale University. The Correspondence series contains a small amount of letters both to and from Snead. The final series holds research done on this collection of material prior to it being aquired by the University of Pittsburgh, consisting primarily of notecards.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: James Arthur Snead was born in Queens, New York, in 1953. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy, graduating cum laude in 1971. After high school, Snead attended Yale, achieving Scholar of the House in Saybrook, and graduating summa cum laude in 1976 with a degree in English. At Yale, Snead's studies focused on James Joyce and Thomas Mann. For his doctorate degree, Snead attended St. John's College, Cambridge, where he graduated with a PhD in English in 1980. This doctoral work led to his 1986 book, Figures of Division: William Faulkner's Major Novels, which explored race in Faulkner's works. While in England, Snead toured around as a keyboardist with a local students' jazz band.

After graduation, Snead lived in West Germany working in finance, where he became fascinated with democracy in Germany. James, or Jamie as he was called, returned to Yale in the early 1980s as an assistant professor of English. During this time, Snead became interested in the way race was depicted in film, leading him to publish academic and popular articles on the subject. Snead, then, moved to the University of Pittsburgh in pursuit of a tenured position. Snead died unexpectedly in 1989, leaving behind many unpublished works.

After his death, Snead's estate published two books of his previously unreleased work. White Screens, Black Images: Hollywood from the Dark Side was published in 1994 and focused on his interest of the portrayal of African Americans in film. Racist Traces and Other Writings, published in 2003, was a collection of essays and fiction. Snead also left behind an unpublished major work called Visions of White, as well as many short stories and poems. In addition, Snead wrote book reviews and various articles on topics such as people of color in film, James Joyce, Thomas Mann, Greek epics, Benito Cereno, and more.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of George T. Snead on December 5, 2017.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Cassidee Knott in January 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Snead Papers, 1966-1989, UA.90.F81, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the written works of James A. Snead, both fiction and non-fiction. His works span from 1972 to 1988. It includes both handwritten and typewritten early drafts, as well as published or circulated materials.While the Non-Fiction subseries is much larger and contains many published works, the Fiction subseries contains many handwritten, unpublished materials. Topics include, but are not limited to: People of Color in Film; German themes; Thomas Mann; and James Joyce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Fiction subseries contains short stories, book proposals, and poetry. Most of these materials had yet to be published before Snead's death. Some materials were published posthumously by Snead's colleagues in White Screens, Black Images: Hollywood from the Dark Side and Racist Traces and Other Writings. Some of the unpublished materials lack titles and are denoted as "Unknown Draft." The majority of the works in this subseries were based around German topics, as well as issues faced by African Americans. Some notable titles from this subseries are the book Visions of White, short stories "A Matter of Peas" and "Notes of a Hybrid," and the poem "Happy for Sun Light."

did.unittitle: "A Smell of Burning Leaves: The Appearance of Oregano" Short Story
Handwritten Draft about a Person Traveling

"Notes of a Hybrid/ Letters from Africa" Drafts
Notion of Going to Oxford Autobiographical Writing Draft

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains unpublished and published non-fiction works by James Snead. Topics for this subseries include: Thomas Mann; James Joyce; Benito Cereno; Book Reviews; William Faulkner; Greek Stories; and Race. This subseries shows the variance in subjects that facinated Snead and how his interests changed over time. A large element of his non-fiction work is his book, Figures of Division, published in 1986 on William Faulkner and his novels. Though this subseries does not contain the book, it does contain early drafts of parts of the book. Notable titles within this subseries include: "Recoding Blackness: Image and Reality in Black Independent Films;" "Misreading Race in Benito Cereno: The Silence of Babo;"and "Repitition and Realism in Ulysses and Der Zauberberg."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of research done by James A. Snead for his various non-ficion works and his own intersts. The research consists of articles and notes on Benito Cereno; books, plays, and poems; German topics; Greek topics; James Joyce; People of Color; poetry; Thomas Mann; William Faulkner; and various other writers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the research done on the novella Benito Cereno by Herman Melville. James Snead was paritcullary interested in racism within the novella. The research includes outlines, articles, and notes.

did.unittitle: Manifesto Packet of Benito Cereno Notes
Monkey in the Manifesto: Benito Cereno Notes on Babo
Outlines, Points to Remember, and Notes for Cereno

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains research on various books, plays, and poems that were of interst to James Snead. A few of the works include: short stories by Franz Kafka; Mrs. Dalloway by Virginia Woolf; Wasteland by T.S. Eliot; and "The Cherry Orchard" play by Anton Chekhov.

"A Week on the Oncord and Merrimack Rivers" by William Drake

Mrs. Dalloway Novel by Virginia Woolf Research Notes
"Sir Giwain" Poem by Anonymous Research Notes
"Volpone" Play by Ben Jonson Research Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries overviews general research done by James Snead that does not fit in other categories, including research on art museums, Freud, and possible paper topics.

did.unittitle: Selections from "The Ash Keeper's Everlasting Passion Week" by Louis Daniel Brodsky
Why is there Salt in the Sea? By Brigite Schwaiger
Yale Review Journal with Note to Snead Concerning Book Reviews

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries covers research done by James Snead on Biermann, music, posters, and various articles. The majority of the research is done in the German.

did.unittitle: "Freedom of Opinion, Freedom of Travel" for Wolf Biermann event at Ruhr-University in Bochum, Germany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains research done by James Snead on Greek works and mythology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries overviews the research done by James Snead on James Joyce and his writings. The research includes general notes and articles,which were most likely used for the Snead's graduate dissertation on Thomas Mann and James Joyce.

did.unittitle: The Room of Infinite Possibilities, History, Hegel, and Joyce Articles
Some Perfactory Romances on Character in Joyce

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the various research of James Snead regarding African Americans and other people of color. Topics include, but are not limited to: Beauty and Fashion, College, Museums, Sports, Film, War, and Racism. This research was conducted later in Snead's life, from 1973 to 1988.

did.unittitle: "Blackness without Blood" by Henry Louis Gates, Jr.
New York City Real Estate Research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains poetry research done by James Snead, including a booklet of poems from Saybrook College in which Snead attended, as well as poetic knowledge papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains James Snead's research on Thomas Mann, which was most likely used for his graduate dissertation on Thomas Mann and James Joyce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries is a collection of James Snead's research on William Faulkner, which was most likely used in part during the writing of Snead's book, Figures of Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries is made up of research on various writers, including Andre Gide, Dante Alighieri, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Herman Lenz, Jaques Lacan, Marcel Proust, Sherman Paul, and others. The research consists of written notes and articles about the writers.

did.unittitle: Emerson's Tragic Sense by Whicher Research
Wordsworth: The History in Imagination by Alan Liu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains classwork, lectures, public speeches, course books, and music created by Snead, primarily documenting his work as an academic.

"The Underground and the Essential in Ellison's Invisible Man" Lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains regular correspondence, as well as parody correspondence. The correspondence is to, from, and about James Snead. The letters range from 1980 to 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains notecards created by Colin MacCabe and Kara Keeling who cataloged a portion of the papers found in this collection before they were deposited in the University of Pittsburgh Archives. The notes outline some of the unidentified works by Snead and aided in the oranization of this collection.
